Posts.Content: On 10/11/2009 will be ok2 wrote: Hi there - I am a veteran on this site for the last year and have gotten some great advice from you guys and gals.  Usual rundown...I am now 36, had a double mastectomy with immediate recon a year ago.  Permanent implants (silicone) are in.  I have been procrastinating on whether or not to get the nipple procedure done.  Should I get the procedure done or just get the tatooing from a tatoo artist?  I have heard some stories about the nipples becoming necrotic and falling off.  Or they completely flatten out, in some women relatively quickly, and become unnoticable anyway.  I am more concerned about them falling off and making me more disfigured.  The scars are bad enough.  Don't get me wrong...I do appreciate that these things can be done in this day and age but I am always that one percent that gets the wierd things going wrong.  One expander was popped with the injection needle in the middle of my chemo treatments and I needed to have it replaced...DURING CHEMO.  Now I have a hernia in the right implant since the day it was put in and need another operation to place mesh under the implant to hold the implant in place and get rid of the bulge that is now there underneath.  Has anyone out there had the nipple procedure done and have pros or cons to share with me so I can have more piece of mind to make my decision???    Thanks!   Hi, I am sorry you have been through so much pain with your treatment and reconstruction.  I had a bilateral mastectomy almost 3 years ago. I had immediate reconstruction with silicone implants.  I agonized for a year over the deision to have nipple reconstruction.  In the end I opted for a local flap reconstruction (the nipple is made from the skin on the breast mound) and tatoos.  The flap proceedure is very simple, painless and can be done in the doctor's office. There is no risk of them "falling off" like in a graft procedure where the tissue comes from the groin area.  One of my nipples did flatten out but my plastic surgeon used some Radiesse (filler) to puff it up  and it looks fine.  My original tatoos done by my plastic surgeon were alright, but later I went to a medical tatoo artist who redid them and they look great.  That said, the tatoo artist can do amazing 3D tatoos that could easily pass for the real thing without any surgery. Another argument for this is that you don't have to worry about wearing a bra with thin clothing because there is no nipple protrusion. For me, getting the nipple reconstruction provided some closure on my breast cancer ordeal.  While no one else may see your breasts, you do and the "mounds" just don't look like real breasts without nipples. It's like a face with no eyes! Good luck and be well. bluedevil
Posts.Title: Nipple reconstruction...to do..or not to do???

Posts.Content: I also had double mastectomies and silicone implants.  My doctors have recommended annual Breast MRIs.  I'm not sure a mamogram would be particularly useful. Good luck!
